trans-unit.source: Configuring Your Azure project using multiple service configurations
trans-unit.target: Configuring Your Azure project using multiple service configurations

trans-unit.source: Configuring Your Azure project using multiple service configurations
trans-unit.target: Configuring Your Azure project using multiple service configurations

trans-unit.source: Configuring an Azure Project
trans-unit.target: Configuring an Azure Project

trans-unit.source: An Azure cloud service project includes two configuration files: ServiceDefinition.csdef and ServiceConfiguration.cscfg.
trans-unit.target: An Azure cloud service project includes two configuration files: ServiceDefinition.csdef and ServiceConfiguration.cscfg.

trans-unit.source: These files are packaged with your Azure cloud service application and deployed to Azure.
trans-unit.target: These files are packaged with your Azure cloud service application and deployed to Azure.

trans-unit.source: The ServiceDefinition.csdef file contains the metadata that is required by the Azure environment for the requirements of your cloud service application, including what roles it contains.
trans-unit.target: The ServiceDefinition.csdef file contains the metadata that is required by the Azure environment for the requirements of your cloud service application, including what roles it contains.

trans-unit.source: This file also contains configuration settings that apply to all instances.
trans-unit.target: This file also contains configuration settings that apply to all instances.

trans-unit.source: These configuration settings can be read at runtime using the Azure Service Hosting Runtime API.
trans-unit.target: These configuration settings can be read at runtime using the Azure Service Hosting Runtime API.

trans-unit.source: This file cannot be updated while your service is running in Azure.
trans-unit.target: This file cannot be updated while your service is running in Azure.

trans-unit.source: The ServiceConfiguration.cscfg file sets values for the configuration settings defined in the service definition file and specifies the number of instances to run for each role.
trans-unit.target: The ServiceConfiguration.cscfg file sets values for the configuration settings defined in the service definition file and specifies the number of instances to run for each role.

trans-unit.source: This file can be updated while your cloud service is running in Azure.
trans-unit.target: This file can be updated while your cloud service is running in Azure.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Tools for Microsoft Visual Studio provide property pages that you can use to set configuration settings stored in these files.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Tools for Microsoft Visual Studio provide property pages that you can use to set configuration settings stored in these files.

trans-unit.source: To access the property pages, double-click the role reference underneath the Azure cloud service project in Solution Explorer, or right-click the role reference and choose Properties, as shown in the following figure.
trans-unit.target: To access the property pages, double-click the role reference underneath the Azure cloud service project in Solution Explorer, or right-click the role reference and choose Properties, as shown in the following figure.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>VS_Solution_Explorer_Roles_Properties</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>VS_Solution_Explorer_Roles_Properties</linkText>

trans-unit.source: For information about the underlying schemas for the service definition and service configuration files, see the <link><linkText>Schema Reference</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For information about the underlying schemas for the service definition and service configuration files, see the <link><linkText>Schema Reference</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: For more information about service configuration, see <link><linkText>Configuring an Application</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about service configuration, see <link><linkText>Configuring an Application</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Configuring role properties
trans-unit.target: Configuring role properties

trans-unit.source: The property pages for a web role and a worker role are similar, although there are a few differences, pointed out in the following sections.
trans-unit.target: The property pages for a web role and a worker role are similar, although there are a few differences, pointed out in the following sections.

trans-unit.source: From the Caching page, you can configure the Azure caching services that are in preview.
trans-unit.target: From the Caching page, you can configure the Azure caching services that are in preview.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>How to: Configure an Azure In-Role Cache</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>How to: Configure an Azure In-Role Cache</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Configuration page
trans-unit.target: Configuration page

trans-unit.source: On the Configuration page, you can set these properties:
trans-unit.target: On the Configuration page, you can set these properties:

trans-unit.source: Instances
trans-unit.target: Instances

trans-unit.source: Set the Instance count property to the number of instances the service should run for this role.
trans-unit.target: Set the Instance count property to the number of instances the service should run for this role.

trans-unit.source: Set the VM size property to Extra Small, Small, Medium, Large, or Extra Large.
trans-unit.target: Set the VM size property to Extra Small, Small, Medium, Large, or Extra Large.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>Configure Sizes for Cloud Services</linkText><title></title></link> .
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>Configure Sizes for Cloud Services</linkText><title></title></link> .

trans-unit.source: Startup Action (Web Role Only)
trans-unit.target: Startup Action (Web Role Only)

trans-unit.source: Set this property to specify that Visual Studio should launch a web browser for either the HTTP endpoints or the HTTPS endpoints, or both when you start debugging.
trans-unit.target: Set this property to specify that Visual Studio should launch a web browser for either the HTTP endpoints or the HTTPS endpoints, or both when you start debugging.

trans-unit.source: The HTTPS endpoint option is available only if you have already defined an HTTPS endpoint for your role.
trans-unit.target: The HTTPS endpoint option is available only if you have already defined an HTTPS endpoint for your role.

trans-unit.source: You can define an HTTPS endpoint on the Endpoints property page.
trans-unit.target: You can define an HTTPS endpoint on the Endpoints property page.

trans-unit.source: If you have already added an HTTPS endpoint, the HTTPS endpoint option is enabled by default, and Visual Studio will launch a browser for this endpoint when you start debugging, in addition to a browser for your HTTP endpoint.
trans-unit.target: If you have already added an HTTPS endpoint, the HTTPS endpoint option is enabled by default, and Visual Studio will launch a browser for this endpoint when you start debugging, in addition to a browser for your HTTP endpoint.

trans-unit.source: This assumes that both startup options are enabled.
trans-unit.target: This assumes that both startup options are enabled.

trans-unit.source: Diagnostics
trans-unit.target: Diagnostics

trans-unit.source: By default, diagnostics is enabled for the Web role.
trans-unit.target: By default, diagnostics is enabled for the Web role.

trans-unit.source: The Azure cloud service project and storage account are set to use the local storage emulator.
trans-unit.target: The Azure cloud service project and storage account are set to use the local storage emulator.

trans-unit.source: When you are ready to deploy to Azure, you can click the builder button (…) to update the storage account to use Azure storage in the cloud.
trans-unit.target: When you are ready to deploy to Azure, you can click the builder button (…) to update the storage account to use Azure storage in the cloud.

trans-unit.source: You can transfer the diagnostics data to the storage account on demand or at automatically scheduled intervals.
trans-unit.target: You can transfer the diagnostics data to the storage account on demand or at automatically scheduled intervals.

trans-unit.source: For more information about Azure diagnostics, see <link><linkText>Collect Logging Data by Using Azure Diagnostics</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about Azure diagnostics, see <link><linkText>Collect Logging Data by Using Azure Diagnostics</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Settings page
trans-unit.target: Settings page

trans-unit.source: On the Settings page, you can add configuration settings for your service.
trans-unit.target: On the Settings page, you can add configuration settings for your service.

trans-unit.source: Configuration settings are name-value pairs.
trans-unit.target: Configuration settings are name-value pairs.

trans-unit.source: Code running in the role can read the values of your configuration settings at runtime using classes provided by the <link><linkText>Azure Managed Library</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Code running in the role can read the values of your configuration settings at runtime using classes provided by the <link><linkText>Azure Managed Library</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Specifically, the <link><linkText>GetConfigurationSettingValue</linkText><title></title></link> method returns the value of a named configuration setting at runtime.
trans-unit.target: Specifically, the <link><linkText>GetConfigurationSettingValue</linkText><title></title></link> method returns the value of a named configuration setting at runtime.

trans-unit.source: Configuring a connection string to a storage account
trans-unit.target: Configuring a connection string to a storage account

trans-unit.source: A connection string is a configuration setting that provides connection and authentication information for the storage emulator or for an Azure storage account.
trans-unit.target: A connection string is a configuration setting that provides connection and authentication information for the storage emulator or for an Azure storage account.

trans-unit.source: Whenever your code must access Azure storage services data – that is, blob, queue, or table data – from code running in a role, you will have to define a connection string for that storage account.
trans-unit.target: Whenever your code must access Azure storage services data – that is, blob, queue, or table data – from code running in a role, you will have to define a connection string for that storage account.

trans-unit.source: A connection string that points to an Azure storage account must use a defined format.
trans-unit.target: A connection string that points to an Azure storage account must use a defined format.

trans-unit.source: For information about how to create connection strings, see <link><linkText>How to Configure Connection Strings</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For information about how to create connection strings, see <link><linkText>How to Configure Connection Strings</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: When you are ready to test your service against the Azure storage services, or when you are ready to deploy your cloud service to Azure, you can change the value of any connection strings to point to your Azure storage account.
trans-unit.target: When you are ready to test your service against the Azure storage services, or when you are ready to deploy your cloud service to Azure, you can change the value of any connection strings to point to your Azure storage account.

trans-unit.source: Click (…), select Enter storage account credentials.
trans-unit.target: Click (…), select Enter storage account credentials.

trans-unit.source: Enter your account information that includes your account name and account key.
trans-unit.target: Enter your account information that includes your account name and account key.

trans-unit.source: In the Storage Account Connection String dialog box, you can also indicate whether you want to use the default HTTPS endpoints (the default option), the default HTTP endpoints, or custom endpoints.
trans-unit.target: In the Storage Account Connection String dialog box, you can also indicate whether you want to use the default HTTPS endpoints (the default option), the default HTTP endpoints, or custom endpoints.

trans-unit.source: You might decide to use custom endpoints if you have registered a custom domain name for your service, as described in <link><linkText>Configure a custom domain name for blob data in an Azure storage account</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: You might decide to use custom endpoints if you have registered a custom domain name for your service, as described in <link><linkText>Configure a custom domain name for blob data in an Azure storage account</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: You must modify your connection strings to point to an Azure storage account before you deploy your service.
trans-unit.target: You must modify your connection strings to point to an Azure storage account before you deploy your service.

trans-unit.source: Failing to do this may cause your role not to start, or to cycle through the initializing, busy, and stopping states.
trans-unit.target: Failing to do this may cause your role not to start, or to cycle through the initializing, busy, and stopping states.

trans-unit.source: Endpoints page
trans-unit.target: Endpoints page

trans-unit.source: A worker role can have any number of HTTP, HTTPS, or TCP endpoints.
trans-unit.target: A worker role can have any number of HTTP, HTTPS, or TCP endpoints.

trans-unit.source: Endpoints can be input endpoints, which are available to external clients, or internal endpoints, which are available to other roles that are running in the service.
trans-unit.target: Endpoints can be input endpoints, which are available to external clients, or internal endpoints, which are available to other roles that are running in the service.

trans-unit.source: To make an HTTP endpoint available to external clients and Web browsers, change the endpoint type to input, and specify a name and a public port number.
trans-unit.target: To make an HTTP endpoint available to external clients and Web browsers, change the endpoint type to input, and specify a name and a public port number.

trans-unit.source: To make an HTTPS endpoint available to external clients and Web browsers, change the endpoint type to input, and specify a name, a public port number, and a management certificate name.
trans-unit.target: To make an HTTPS endpoint available to external clients and Web browsers, change the endpoint type to input, and specify a name, a public port number, and a management certificate name.

trans-unit.source: Note that before you can specify a management certificate, you must define the certificate on the Certificates property page.
trans-unit.target: Note that before you can specify a management certificate, you must define the certificate on the Certificates property page.

trans-unit.source: To make an endpoint available for internal access by other roles in the cloud service, change the endpoint type to internal, and specify a name and possible private ports for this endpoint.
trans-unit.target: To make an endpoint available for internal access by other roles in the cloud service, change the endpoint type to internal, and specify a name and possible private ports for this endpoint.

trans-unit.source: Local storage page
trans-unit.target: Local storage page

trans-unit.source: You can use the Local Storage property page to reserve one or more local storage resources for a role.
trans-unit.target: You can use the Local Storage property page to reserve one or more local storage resources for a role.

trans-unit.source: A local storage resource is a reserved directory in the file system of the Azure virtual machine in which an instance of a role is running.
trans-unit.target: A local storage resource is a reserved directory in the file system of the Azure virtual machine in which an instance of a role is running.

trans-unit.source: For more information about how to work with local storage resources, see <link><linkText>Configure Local Storage Resources</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about how to work with local storage resources, see <link><linkText>Configure Local Storage Resources</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Certificates page
trans-unit.target: Certificates page

trans-unit.source: On the Certificates page, you can associate certificates with your role.
trans-unit.target: On the Certificates page, you can associate certificates with your role.

trans-unit.source: The certificates that you add can be used to configure your HTTPS endpoints on the Endpoints property page.
trans-unit.target: The certificates that you add can be used to configure your HTTPS endpoints on the Endpoints property page.

trans-unit.source: The Certificates property page adds information about your certificates to your service configuration.
trans-unit.target: The Certificates property page adds information about your certificates to your service configuration.

trans-unit.source: Note that your certificates are not packaged with your service; you must upload your certificates separately to Azure through the <link><linkText>Azure Platform Management portal</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Note that your certificates are not packaged with your service; you must upload your certificates separately to Azure through the <link><linkText>Azure Platform Management portal</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: To associate a certificate with your role, provide a name for the certificate.
trans-unit.target: To associate a certificate with your role, provide a name for the certificate.

trans-unit.source: You use this name to refer to the certificate when you configure an HTTPS endpoint on the Endpoints property page.
trans-unit.target: You use this name to refer to the certificate when you configure an HTTPS endpoint on the Endpoints property page.

trans-unit.source: Next, specify whether the certificate store is Local Machine or Current User and the name of the store.
trans-unit.target: Next, specify whether the certificate store is Local Machine or Current User and the name of the store.

trans-unit.source: Finally, enter the certificate's thumbprint.
trans-unit.target: Finally, enter the certificate's thumbprint.

trans-unit.source: If the certificate is in the Current User\Personal (My) store, you can enter the certificate's thumbprint by selecting the certificate from a populated list.
trans-unit.target: If the certificate is in the Current User\Personal (My) store, you can enter the certificate's thumbprint by selecting the certificate from a populated list.

trans-unit.source: If it resides in any other location, enter the thumbprint value by hand.
trans-unit.target: If it resides in any other location, enter the thumbprint value by hand.

trans-unit.source: When you add a certificate from the certificate store, any intermediate certificates are automatically added to the configuration settings for you.
trans-unit.target: When you add a certificate from the certificate store, any intermediate certificates are automatically added to the configuration settings for you.

trans-unit.source: These intermediate certificates must also be uploaded to Azure in order to correctly configure your service for SSL.
trans-unit.target: These intermediate certificates must also be uploaded to Azure in order to correctly configure your service for SSL.

trans-unit.source: Any management certificates that you associate with your service apply to your service only when it is running in the cloud.
trans-unit.target: Any management certificates that you associate with your service apply to your service only when it is running in the cloud.

trans-unit.source: When your service is running in the local development environment, it uses a standard certificate that is managed by the compute emulator.
trans-unit.target: When your service is running in the local development environment, it uses a standard certificate that is managed by the compute emulator.

trans-unit.source: Configuring the Azure cloud service project
trans-unit.target: Configuring the Azure cloud service project

trans-unit.source: To configure settings that apply to an entire Azure cloud service project, you first open the shortcut menu for that project node, and then you choose Properties to open its property pages.
trans-unit.target: To configure settings that apply to an entire Azure cloud service project, you first open the shortcut menu for that project node, and then you choose Properties to open its property pages.

trans-unit.source: The following table shows those property pages.
trans-unit.target: The following table shows those property pages.

trans-unit.source: Property Page
trans-unit.target: Property Page

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: Application
trans-unit.target: Application

trans-unit.source: From this page, you can display information about the version of Azure Tools that this cloud service project uses, and you can upgrade to the current version of the tools.
trans-unit.target: From this page, you can display information about the version of Azure Tools that this cloud service project uses, and you can upgrade to the current version of the tools.

trans-unit.source: Build Events
trans-unit.target: Build Events

trans-unit.source: From this page, you can set pre-build and post-build events.
trans-unit.target: From this page, you can set pre-build and post-build events.

trans-unit.source: Development
trans-unit.target: Development

trans-unit.source: From this page, you can specify build configuration instructions and the conditions under which any post-build events are run.
trans-unit.target: From this page, you can specify build configuration instructions and the conditions under which any post-build events are run.

trans-unit.source: Web
trans-unit.target: Web

trans-unit.source: From this page, you can configure settings that relate to the web server.
trans-unit.target: From this page, you can configure settings that relate to the web server.

trans-unit.source: See Also
trans-unit.target: See Also

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Azure Tools for Microsoft Visual Studio</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Azure Tools for Microsoft Visual Studio</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: test
trans-unit.target: test
